title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 14
author: Various
snippet: We wereseveral miles distant from Mitchelslacks; but, as I considered myselfquite familiar with the ground, I struck immediately over the pathlesshill, by what I termed a _near cut_, instead of retracing the stream fora couple of miles, and then crossing the Dod by a cart track.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 14
author: Various
snippet: I was quickly and successively basketing trout aftertrout, humming all the while some old Scottish sonnet, and calling in mylittle dog, _Don_, from the sheep who were pasturing on the adjoininghill, named the Dod, when a voice from the depths of the mist and thesolitude reached my ear.

snippet: Dod, sir, I'm a lone man! If I was to tak' her in, it's highlypossible the hellicat would try and gar me marry her when he turned up."

title: Our coaching trip,
author: Carnegie, Andrew
snippet: I remember well that Aunty Morrison, Uncle Lauder, Dod, and other friends, stood on the quay and waved farewell.

title: Our coaching trip,
author: Carnegie, Andrew
snippet: and the world lay all before us where to choose, Dod, Vandy, Harry, and I walked through Southern England  with knapsacks on our backs'.

title: Our coaching trip,
author: Carnegie, Andrew
snippet: Long enough ago to permit us to sing," For we are boys, merry, merry boys,"and the world lay all before us where to choose, Dod,Vandy, Harry, and I walked through Southern England with knapsacks on our backs.
